content.description:
A little on the tall side, I remember a buried rock edge landing, I rarely see chalk on this line.  I remember pulling an edge off up high too, so watch yourself. 

  Straightforward pulling gets you up this problem.
content.location: A few feet right of the crack problem on the Bloody Tissue boulder, go straight up the line of holds.  You may want to scout the top out before committing.

content.description:
This is a cool problem with mostly good handholds and thinner feet most of the time. 

  Move up small huecos to the top of the arete. trend left around the corner to the steep left side and top out on thin crimps but with a great heelhook.
content.protection: Pads and spotter. There is a built up ledge below the top of this problem but if you fall you will land near the back edge of it and so a spot to keep you from teetering of the edge is nice.
content.location: This is the down hill arete on the second warm up boulder that is just above the trail as it heads back to the gully. Start from the lowest good hueco edges.

content.description:
A nice warm up that follows the crack on the nice steep featured face. 

  Sink the two pockets and stand on some great feet. Pull up to jugs in the crack. Continue up the crack with holds on the left.
content.location: This follows the nice steep seam on the featured face on the boulder that the trail passes as it heads back to the gully.

content.description:
Good warm up, some of the holds are a bit spooky, pull down not out. 

  From a stand start on good edges, move up the steep wall with long pulls between honking jugs, most of them are actually threaders. Top out over the big lump at the lip.
content.location: This is the face between the Left Arete and Crack on the boulder that the approach trail passes as it heads back towards the gully.

content.description:
There are 3 boulders in this area with problems on them. The first two sit side by side right where the trail up the left side of the gully makes a turn back right towards the gully, for the purpose of locating problemswe will call the first one Boulder A and the one behind it Boulder B. The last boulder is bigger and more featured than the first two. One face in particular is overhanging with tons of positive edges and pockets, great warming up, we'll call this Boulder C. 

  EDIT: Boulder C is the "Bloody Tissue" boulder
